title: Magpie99
author: Magpie99
content: üí≠The United Nations has decided to send financial aid to refugees displaced by the war in Ukraine through crypto currency 'USD Coin (USDC); But the reality of the volatile crypto market calls into question its rationale.The United Nations Refugee Agency (UNHCR) supports the refugees by providing them with the necessary financial aid to meet their basic living and accommodation expenses. On Thursday, the organization announced that victims of Russia's military aggression in Ukraine will receive financial aid through cryptocurrency. Refugees can collect cash in exchange for crypto currency sent by the organization through the MoneyGram service anywhere in the world.USDC is known as a 'stable coin'; That is, the valuation of the crypto currency is adjusted to the US dollar. Stablecoins are considered relatively reliable digital currencies due to their support of mainstream currency systems.Supporters of UNHCR's initiative say that displaced people will receive financial aid more quickly in this process; The risk of misappropriation during fund transfer will be reduced. But many concerned are skeptical about the effectiveness of the process, according to the Washington Post.Critics say it will add an extra step to the process of getting refugee assistance, the newspaper wrote. On the other hand, there are fears of additional complications due to the volatility of the global crypto market throughout the year.Molly White, a critic of the crypto sector, commented on this UN initiative, "They are directly asking people to participate in crypto transactions." But White pointed out that some parts of the crypto sector as a whole are at greater risk.The Washington Post did not have an immediate response from UNHCR to the criticism."Speed is of particular importance in humanitarian work," said Carolina Lindholm Billing, UNHCR's representative in Ukraine, when announcing the delivery of aid in cryptocurrencies. It is also important to provide people with multiple means of cooperation; One thing does not fit all.‚ÄùVolatility has prevailed in the global crypto market throughout the year; The overall situation has further deteriorated in the last few months. Leading crypto exchange FTX declares company bankrupt; Sam Bankman-Fried, the company's former CEO, has been arrested on charges of fraud and money laundering.On the other hand, Bitcoin, the top currency of the crypto market, has lost a lot of value. The price of the once stable crypto currency 'TeraUSD' has dropped below three more zeros after the decimal point.But since the beginning of the Ukraine war, the relevance of crypto currency in the scenario has been noticeable. In the early days of the war, the Ukrainian government raised nearly $100 million in crypto-currencies.Now the United Nations has decided to launch a pilot project to provide financial aid through crypto currency in the cities of Kyiv, Lviv and Vinnytsia.According to the Washington Post, officials have demanded a six-month review of the utility of this technology service among victims. But it is not yet clear how successful the UN experiment has been.Displaced people must first download a virtual wallet app called 'Vibrant' on their smartphones to receive UN financial aid. Funds will first arrive in the app's account as USDC; Refugees can then collect euros or dollars in exchange for that crypto currency.The Washington Post reports that USDC is a cryptocurrency based on the 'Stellar Blockchain'. Its program is written by the 'Stellar Development Foundation'; Its main function is to promote the Stellar Blockchain.Officials of the organization claimed that their humanitarian activities were limited due to geographical limitations. But it will be possible to expand its scope through crypto currency.üî∏Ukrainian government officials, however, welcomed the UN initiative. "For Ukrainians fleeing for their lives and especially those without access to banks ... this could serve as a last resort for survival," said Oleksandr Borniakov, the country's deputy minister for digital transformation.But White fears that the need to download a wallet to access the service will expose refugees to the dangers of the crypto world.‚ÄúMost crypto wallets always want you to buy more crypto currency,‚Äù he told The Washington Post.In this, the refugees can invest the aid money in other cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. And at the end of the day, White fears that it could turn into a gamble.He thinks that crypto currency companies will benefit in this situation. Acknowledging the importance of aid money going into the hands of refugees, he said, "It is not actually helping people. It's not about how much money we're sending to refugees in Ukraine, it's about demonstrating the use of stablecoins."‚ú¥Ô∏èAccording to critics, the use of stablecoins is more important than providing financial aid to refugees.What is your opinion on this‚ùì

If more funds and aids is given to Ukraine to care for the lost ones and relations, this will help then in a long way.In general, the UN initiative to provide financial assistance to refugees from Ukraine in USDC stablecoin deserves approval from any side. The most significant international organization has actually recognized that cryptocurrency is superior to conventional currency in the simplicity and versatility of its use and that in this case, the currency in the form of stablecoins is the easiest and most affordable to transfer to refugees, wherever they are. comments.author: dwminer1
comments.body: I admit I have mixed feelings about this. It all depends on the scale on which it is to be done. On the one hand, it would probably revive the market a bit, because probably some of these stablecoins would be invested in bitcoin or other cryptocurrencies. However, on the other hand, giving cryptocurrencies to many people who have had little or no experience with cryptocurrencies so far, does not bode well. Even experienced users sometimes lose cryptocurrencies, either by their own mistakes or by the actions of scammers. I am sure that in the case of massive financial assistance paid in cryptocurrencies, scammers and hackers would get the most. And in the mainstream, of course, the message would be that cryptocurrencies, not users, are bad. However, if this experiment were successful, it would be a huge step towards widespread crypto adoption. I think the subject is worth the risk.

If more funds and aids is given to Ukraine to care for the lost ones and relations, this will help then in a long way.This is, in principle, a good idea. Since refugees from Ukraine are now in many countries where there are various features of their banking system, stablecoin assistance will help to ignore this. All that is needed in this case is to provide the UN with a list of such refugees and their wallet address. On the other hand, this will force Ukrainians to become more familiar with the work of cryptocurrency wallets and will allow in practice to compare the efficiency of the banking system and cryptocurrencies. In general, it will be useful for Ukrainians. But how they will use the USDC provided to them is their business.
